title: A man traveled at 40 kmph. Had he increased speed by 16 kmph, he would have covered 80 km more at the same time. What is the actual distance travelled by him? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let the time taken is t hrs And distance is d km In first case speed is 40kmph t=d/40 hrs In second case speed is 40+16=56kmph And distance covered is 80 km more as usual t=d+80/56 hrs Time taken is same in both the cases so equate both the equation d/40=d+80/56 d/5=d+80/7 7d=5d+400 2d=400 d=200 km

By travelling 16 kmph faster, the man would have covered an extra 80km in the time of his travel. From this statement his travel time = (80 km)/(16 km per hour) = 5 hour. The actual distance travelled by him in 5 hour of his travel at a uniform speed of 40 kmph = 40 km per hour × 5 hour = 200 km.
Let the time taken be x hours 56x - 40x = 80 16x = 80 x = 5 hours ANSWER distance traveled = 5*40 = 200 km

let the actual distance be x km. with speed of 40 km ph , the time taken is x/40. if the speed increased by 16 kmph the distance increases by 80 km the time is (x+80) /56. both the ratios are equal that is x/40 = (x+80)/56. solving this we get x=200 km. that is the actual distance travelled is 200 km.

Let the time taken in both cases be T hours and the distance covered in the first case be x km. According to the question, T = x/40 T = (x + 80)/56 Comparing the two equations, x/40 = (x + 80)/56 7x = 5x + 400 x = 200 So, the distance covered in the first case is 200 km.
